abstract_summ: One of the widely used mathematical models of long-term spreading of epidemics are the so-called deterministic compartmental models (SIR/SEIR type models).We perform parameter estimation, uncertainty analysis and model selection for a range of established epidemiological models.Current epidemiological models can in principle model the temporal evolution of a pandemic.METHODS: Our meteorological model is based on the regression model developed by AB and JS, and it is tuned with influenza surveillance data obtained from SISSS.(1) presenting a two step procedure for model fitting to Covid-19 data (2) constraining transmission coefficients as well as R0~ and R(t), for a set of most affected countries and (3) releasing a python package PyCov19 that can used to fit a set of compartmental models with time varying coefficients to Covid-19 data.
title_summ: Uncertainty Quantification in Epidemiological Models for COVID-19 PandemicA data first approach to modelling Covid-19A minimal and adaptive prediction strategy for critical resource planning in a pandemicEstimating the state of the Covid-19 epidemic in France using a non-Markovian modelModel calibration, nowcasting, and operational prediction of the COVID-19 pandemicEpilocal: a real-time tool for local epidemic monitoringFast and Accurate Forecasting of COVID-19 Deaths Using the SIkJ$\alpha$ ModelForecasting the outcome and estimating the epidemic model parameters from the fatality time series in COVID-19 outbreaksA Two-Phase Dynamic Contagion Model for COVID-19Short-Term Covid-19 Forecast for LatecomersThe TVBG-SEIR spline model for analysis of COVID-19 spread, and a Tool for prediction scenariosLearning to Forecast and Forecasting to Learn from the COVID-19 PandemicGlobal Short-Term Forecasting of Covid-19 CasesEvaluating the impact of the weather conditions on the influenza propagationCOVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan demonstrates the limitations of publicly available case numbers for epidemiological modelling.
title_abstract_phrases: One of the widely used mathematical models of long-term spreading of epidemics are the so-called deterministic compartmental models (SIR/SEIR type models).We perform parameter estimation, uncertainty analysis and model selection for a range of established epidemiological models.A minimal and adaptive prediction strategy for critical resource planning in a pandemicCurrent epidemiological models can in principle model the temporal evolution of a pandemic.METHODS: Our meteorological model is based on the regression model developed by AB and JS, and it is tuned with influenza surveillance data obtained from SISSS.For cumulative data, we also consider a logistic parameterisation of the hazard function.
